programs.name: Free Cataract Surgery Project
programs.donor: Jaco Foundation (Canada) - Coordinated via Amico Corporation
programs.beneficiaries: 500 low-income elders per month (300 surgeries at HASL Eye Hospital; 200 in government hospitals)
programs.date: March 2025 (Project start / sponsorship period reported in FY 2024/25)
programs.mini_description: A monthly initiative funded by the Jaco Foundation (Canada) enabling 500 free cataract surgeries to restore sight, dignity, and independence.
programs.description:
The Free Cataract Surgery Project is a vital initiative sponsored by the Jaco Foundation (Canada) and coordinated through Amico Corporation. With a generous donation of USD 25,000, the project enables 500 free cataract surgeries every month for low-income elders.

The project operates on a split-service model: 300 surgeries are conducted at the HelpAge Eye Hospital in Wellawatte, while 200 are performed in partner government hospitals island-wide. This sponsorship covers surgical costs and lenses, directly contributing to the mission of eliminating preventable blindness and restoring dignity and independence to hundreds of seniors each month.

service_model.allocation: 300 surgeries at HelpAge Eye Hospital; 200 surgeries at Government Hospitals.
service_model.goal: To restore sight, dignity, and independence to low-income elders.

programs.beneficiaries: 145 camps serving ~27,000 elders total (11,449 medical / 15,820 eye screenings).

programs.mini_description: Two mobile medical/eye buses delivering free healthcare island-wide. FY 24/25 Stats: 145 camps, 12,178 spectacles distributed, and 3,604 cataracts identified.
programs.description:
HASL operates two Mobile Medical Unit buses that travel across Sri Lanka to provide free medical and eye care to elders lacking access to healthcare. In FY 2024/25, the programme conducted 145 camps, achieving massive reach: 11,449 medical screenings, 15,820 eye screenings, 12,178 spectacles distributed, and 3,604 cataracts identified for referral.

**Key Initiatives:**
* **Supreme Care Jana Suwa Yathra:** Launched in May 2023, this partnership has conducted 95 weekly camps, benefiting over 300 people weekly with the ambitious goal of reaching all 14,022 GN divisions.
* **Darley Butler Camps:** A generous contribution of Rs. 2.2 million enabled 20 specific camps. This initiative notably included the distribution of adult diapers, bringing essential comfort and dignity to many elders.

programs.name: Home Care Division
programs.donor: HASL Programme Funding, Community Donations & CSR Partnerships

budget.amount: Operates under HASL Programme & Home Care Division budgets

programs.beneficiaries: 1,889 elders served in FY 2024/25; Older persons requiring support to live independently.
programs.mini_description: A key service supporting 1,889+ elders to live safely and independently in their own homes through trained caregiver assistance and regular monitoring.
programs.description:
The Home Care Assistance Program is dedicated to supporting older persons to live safely, comfortably, and independently in their own homes. HelpAge’s home-care model allows elders to remain with their families—avoiding the need for institutional care—while receiving support with daily living, health needs, and meaningful companionship. 

In the 2024/25 financial year, the division demonstrated significant impact, providing assistance to 1,889 elders and processing 740 new client requests. To ensure high standards, the team conducted 1,073 monitoring visits and trained 172 new carers.

service_model.approach: Promotes independent living and dignity by allowing elders to remain with families instead of institutional care.
service_model.quality_assurance: All Home Care Assistants are trained by a professional resource panel. Staff monitor and supervise caregivers daily to ensure consistent, high-standard care.
service_model.assessment_process: Upon request, a Matron or Assistant Matron assesses the client's dependency level. A suitable caregiver is assigned, and the case is allocated to a Field Office for ongoing supervision.
service_model.monitoring: A dedicated team (Matrons, Field Officers, Development Officers) carries out regular visits (1,073 visits in FY 24/25) to assess care quality, gather feedback, and provide on-the-job training.

programs.name: Flood Response Project – Global Emergency Fund (GEF) – HAI
programs.beneficiaries: 1,967 older people supported in total (1,167 families under Project 01). Targeted older-person-headed households.
programs.mini_description: Emergency response providing life-saving food packs, essential non-food items, and disability equipment to 1,967 flood-affected elders to ensure safety and dignity.
programs.description:
During the devastating floods of 2024–2025, HelpAge Sri Lanka implemented a life-saving response funded by HelpAge International’s Global Emergency Fund. The project focused on ensuring the safety, comfort, and dignity of 1,967 older people across the Western, Southern, Northern, and Eastern provinces.

Specific activities (Project 01) ran from June to September 2024, reaching 1,167 families in districts such as Kalutara, Gampaha, Galle, and Matara. Distributions included dry food packs (rice, dhal) and essential non-food items (hygiene kits, buckets, soap, sarongs). Crucially, the response also provided disability equipment to vulnerable elders, ensuring they could navigate the crisis with independence.

programs.name: Flood Response Project – UNFPA
programs.beneficiaries: 2,372 elders supported in total; includes 1,268 senior women who received specialized hygiene kits.
programs.mini_description: A gender-sensitive emergency response providing food, disability aids, and 1,268 hygiene kits to older women facing additional risks in disaster zones.
programs.description:
In disaster situations, older women often face unique risks due to age and gender. With funding from UNFPA (USD 123,733.63), HelpAge Sri Lanka implemented a targeted response between December 2024 and March 2025 to support 2,372 elders affected by floods. 

The project focused on restoring dignity and safety by providing food packs, essential non-food items, and disability equipment, allowing elders to rebuild their lives within their familiar environments. A key component was the distribution of 1,268 specialized hygiene kits to senior women across Jaffna (634 kits) and Ampara (634 kits), specifically addressing menstrual and hygiene needs often overlooked in general relief efforts.

service_model.approach: Gender-sensitive humanitarian action focusing on the intersectional risks of age and gender in disaster zones.
service_model.distribution_strategy: Targeted DS divisions in Northern (Jaffna) and Eastern (Ampara) provinces.
service_model.items_provided: Hygiene kits, dry food rations, non-food essentials, and mobility/disability equipment.

programs.name: SHAPE Project (Strategic Humanitarian Assessment and Participatory Empowerment)
programs.beneficiaries: HASL staff (3 staff trained internationally; wider team reached via in-country cascade training)
programs.mini_description: A capacity-building initiative strengthening HASL's humanitarian response through specialized training in Safeguarding, Inclusion Standards (HIS), and Emergency Response.
programs.description:
The SHAPE Project, funded by HelpAge International (USD 7,949), is designed to strengthen local organizations to prepare for and respond to humanitarian emergencies effectively. The project facilitates an internal transformation to ensure better preparedness and improved services for older people during crises.

Three HASL staff members attended an initial 5-day training in Kathmandu (23–27 Sep 2024). Upon their return, they conducted a cascade training session at the HASL Head Office (11–12 Nov 2024) to transfer knowledge on critical areas such as Safeguarding, Humanitarian Inclusion Standards (HIS), and Resource Mobilization.

service_model.approach: Internal capacity building to institutionalize humanitarian standards.
service_model.methodology: Train-the-trainer model (International delegates training local staff).
service_model.goal: To ensure organizational readiness for future humanitarian emergencies.

programs.name: HASOP Project – HelpAge Deutschland / BMZ
programs.beneficiaries: Vulnerable older people over 55 in Galle, Matara, and Hambantota. Beneficiaries selected via SCCs and local authorities.
programs.mini_description: A holistic project funded by BMZ to support vulnerable elders over 55 in the Southern Province through empowerment, capacity building, and dignity promotion.
programs.description:
The HASOP Project, supported by HelpAge Deutschland with funding from BMZ (budget €133,333.25), is a one-year initiative running from December 2024 to November 2025. It targets vulnerable older people over the age of 55 across multiple divisions in the Galle, Matara, and Hambantota districts.

The project employs a holistic approach focused on empowerment, capacity building, and ensuring dignity for marginalized older people. Activities include strengthening Senior Citizens’ Committees (SCCs), staff training on safeguards, and leadership development to ensure sustainable community support.

service_model.approach: Holistic support system focusing on empowerment and dignity.
service_model.beneficiary_selection: Participatory process involving Senior Citizens’ Committees (SCCs), Divisional Secretariats, and project teams to ensure the most vulnerable are reached.

programs.name: World Health Survey Plus (WHS+) – WHO
programs.beneficiaries: National health sector, Department of Census and Statistics, and the general public (via improved health policy).
programs.mini_description: A national survey project strengthening health data systems and SDG monitoring to support evidence-based policy.
programs.description:
The World Health Survey Plus (WHS+) is a national survey project aims to strengthen Sri Lanka’s health data systems and contribute to the monitoring of global health and Sustainable Development Goal (SDG) indicators. 

Supported by a budget of USD 160,195, the project runs from November 2024 to June 2025. By ensuring high-quality data collection, the initiative directly contributes to evidence-based health policy development in the country.

service_model.role: HelpAge Sri Lanka plays a key operational role in the survey implementation.
activities: Collaborating with the Department of Census and Statistics
Translating survey tools into Sinhala and Tamil
Supporting fieldwork and ensuring data quality

programs.name: Direct Mail Campaign 2023/2024
programs.donor: Public donors and loyal supporters (Individual contributions via mailed packs)
programs.beneficiaries: Needy elders requiring vision restoration (main theme), Mobile Medical Camps, Disability Equipment, and Day Care Centre support.
programs.mini_description: The highest income-earning fundraising activity, mailing 60,000+ packs to donors during Vesak, IDOP, and Christmas to support elder vision restoration.
programs.description:
Initiated in 1991, the Direct Mail Fundraising Campaign remains the highest income-earning fundraising activity for HelpAge Sri Lanka. During the reporting period, the campaign achieved the second-highest total in its history, generating a turnover of Rs. 21.7 million. 

Approximately 60,000 donation packs were mailed to dedicated and prospective donors. The campaign strategy revolves around three key seasonal peaks: the Vesak season (May), the International Day of Older Persons (October), and the Christmas/New Year season (December/January). While the primary theme is helping less privileged elders restore their vision, funds raised also support Mobile Medical Camps, disability equipment distribution, and the Day Care Centre.

service_model.approach: Cyclical solicitation via physical mail packs sent to a database of loyal and prospective donors.
key_campaigns: International Day of Older Persons Campaign (October)

programs.name: Greeting Cards Project & 'Give the Gift of Sight' Campaign
programs.donor: Hayleys Group PLC (Major Sponsor), Corporate Donors, International Associations (UK Women's, Spanish Committee), & Retail Partners
programs.beneficiaries: Disadvantaged elderly requiring cataract surgeries (e.g., 260 surgeries sponsored by Hayleys Group). Campaign reached over 300,000 consumers.
programs.mini_description: A transformative year achieving Rs. 18.2M revenue (3x growth) through the 'Give the Gift of Sight' campaign, where bulk card purchases sponsored cataract surgeries.
programs.description:
The 2023/2024 fiscal year marked a historic milestone for the Greeting Cards Division. Despite digital trends reducing demand for traditional cards, the division pivoted to a 'Corporate Compassion' model via the 'Give the Gift of Sight' campaign. This initiative, where purchasing 200 cards equated to sponsoring one cataract surgery, resonated deeply with donors. 

**Performance:** Revenue surged from Rs. 6.05M (22/23) to Rs. 18.27M (23/24). A total of 108,400 seasonal cards were printed, with 91,083 total cards sold (including 79,717 seasonal and 6,000 corporate birthday cards). 

**Major Sponsorship:** Hayleys Group PLC led with a monumental Rs. 5.2 million contribution, sponsoring 260 surgeries. 

**Top Donors & Partners:** 
* **Campaign Donors:** Hayleys PLC, St. John's College Jaffna (80's Batch), Sindhi Charitable Trust, UK Women's Association, Spanish Committee (Intl Bazaar). 
* **Corporate Purchasers:** Omega Line Ltd, Vallible Finance, Berendina Micro Investments, Tokyo Cement, Ceylon Bank Employee's Union. 
* **Retail Purchasers:** Sarasavi Bookshop, Unik Creations, Arpico Super Centre, M.D. Gunasena, Vijitha Yapa Bookshop. 
* **Individual Donors:** Mr. Niren Devendraraja, Ms. Priyanthi Fernando, Ms. Radhika De Silva, Mr. Sritharan Seevaratnam, Mr. Rohan Karr.

service_model.approach: Shifted from traditional retail to 'Cause-Marketing'. The 'Gift of Sight' theme allowed corporates to treat card purchases as CSR/Sponsorships rather than just stationery expenses.
service_model.quality_assurance: Focused on product innovation (26 new designs) and high-end positioning to gain entry into ethical markets like the Good Market and high-end malls.
service_model.assessment_process: Identified new market segments including overseas diaspora associations and high-net-worth individuals to bypass local economic challenges.
service_model.monitoring: Efficient inventory management via stock counts and targeted marketing. Personalized letters were used to drive corporate sales, resulting in 126 corporate clients.

programs.name: Tills Project
programs.donor: Retail partnerships (Cargills Food City, Keells Super Centres, Banks, Restaurants, Pharmacies)
programs.beneficiaries: Revenue supports Eye Hospital cataract surgeries and HASL programmes
programs.mini_description: Established in 1990, this project collects micro-donations via 2,033 tills island-wide, with recent 8% growth driven by tourism in coastal areas.
programs.description:
Initiated in 1990, the Tills Project places HASL collection tills in high-traffic locations including supermarkets, banks, restaurants, and pharmacies. During the period under review, the project raised Rs. 6,354,167, reflecting an 8% growth in income compared to the previous year (2022/2023). 

A total of 2,033 tills were active across the Central, Southern, Uwa, and Western provinces. notably, 1,342 of these were placed in the Western Province, with 180 key units located at Cargills Food Cities and Keells Super Centres in Colombo. The report specifically highlights an increase in contributions from southern coastal areas such as Galle, Hikkaduwa, and Mirissa, attributed to the resurgence of tourist arrivals.

programs.donor: Supreme Global Holdings, Dialog Axiata PLC, Habib Bank, Milco, Peoples Leasing, Richard Pieris Co., Sri Lanka Ports Authority

budget.amount: Rs. 12,551,372 (Contribution from Dialog Star Points + other CSR funds)

programs.beneficiaries: Needy elders receiving free cataract surgeries, 300 elders screened weekly via 48 Mobile Medical Camps, and recipients of disability aids.

programs.description:
Established in 2011, the Special Projects Division focuses on securing funds from the Corporate Social Responsibility (CSR) budgets of leading Sri Lankan companies. During the review period, the division successfully financed free cataract surgeries, mobile medical camps, and disability aids. 

**Key Achievements:**
* **Supreme Global Holdings:** Sponsored 48 Mobile Medical and Eye Camps (double camps every Saturday), screening ~300 elders weekly.
* **Dialog Axiata Partnership:** A long-standing partner since 2010. Through SMS campaigns, customers donated Star Points (raising Rs. 438,306.55). The total contribution from Dialog Star Points initiatives amounted to Rs. 12,551,372.
* **Share As You Earn (SAYE):** This programme encourages voluntary monthly salary contributions from corporate employees. New partnerships were forged with Habib Bank, Milco (Pvt) Ltd, Peoples Leasing & Finance PLC, Richard Pieris Co. PLC, and the Sri Lanka Ports Authority (SLPA).

service_model.approach: Submits tailored project proposals to CSR divisions of leading corporates, inviting them to allocate annual welfare budgets to elder care.

programs.name: Sponsor a Grandparent (SaG) Programme
programs.beneficiaries: 10,750 elders (MMU services), 112 livelihood beneficiaries, 50 Home Care Volunteers, and students/educators via YEP.
programs.date: Ongoing annual programme (Performance stats reported for current review period)
programs.mini_description: A holistic initiative strengthening community support for elders through medical camps, livelihood grants (Rs. 1.3M distributed), rights advocacy, and intergenerational youth programmes.
programs.description:
The Sponsor a Grandparent (SaG) Programme is one of HelpAge Sri Lanka’s most meaningful initiatives, designed to uplift older people by ensuring they live with dignity, better health, and community support. The programme operates on a holistic model that brings essential services directly to villages. 

**Key Impacts:**
* **Healthcare:** The Mobile Medical Units (MMU) benefited 10,750 elders this year, providing 3,769 eye screenings, 3,251 medical screenings, and identifying 913 cataract cases.
* **Economic Support:** Since Dec 2022, livelihood initiatives have empowered 112 beneficiaries (including elders with disabilities) with microloans totaling Rs. 1,325,000 to start businesses like pottery, gardening, and sweet making.
* **Capacity Building:** The programme trains Home Care Volunteers and school educators (via YEP) to build a society that respects and cares for its aging population.

service_model.advocacy_and_rights: Ensures elders' voices are heard through awareness campaigns and community mobilization to influence policy and protect well-being.
service_model.youth_education_yep: Trainers of Training (ToT) programmes equip school principals and zonal directors to guide students, fostering intergenerational harmony and respect for elders.
service_model.healthcare_delivery: Island-wide Mobile Medical Unit (MMU) camps provided: 3,769 Eye Screenings, 3,251 Medical Screenings, 2,817 Spectacles distributed, and 913 Cataracts identified.
service_model.volunteer_training: Annual 5-day residential training for 50 senior citizens as Home Care Volunteers, teaching basic nursing, first aid, psychological care, and physiotherapy.
service_model.livelihood_support: Microloans (approx. Rs. 10,000 per person) for income generation (broom making, clay pottery, lamp wicks). Total distributed: Rs. 1,325,000 to 112 beneficiaries.
service_model.holistic_care: Includes spiritual development programmes for inner peace, environmental conservation projects (tree planting), and the donation of assistive devices (wheelchairs, walkers) to restore independence.
